ABSTRACT

The increasing global concern to ensure better energy sustainability and environmental preservation has, over the past years, boosted the development of increasingly advanced renewable technologies. In this context, organic solar cells based on conjugated polymers have proved to be a good option with regard to cost reduction, ease of production on an industrial scale and device flexibility, even though their commercialization is still limited due to a relatively low efficiency. Polymers and copolymers based on thiophene, in particular, are among the most studied materials in literature for application in the development of organic photovoltaic devices, due, among other factors, to their optoelectronic and electroluminescent properties, as well as their therm al stability.

In this work, we investigated the electronic structure and morphology of thin films of copolymer F8T2, a derivative of poly(thiophene), as well as samples treated with the additive DIO and subjected to heat treatment . The addition of the PMMA insulating polymer was also studied. The measurements were carried out at the SXS beamline at the Brazilian Synchrotron Light Source (LNLS) using the NEXAFS technique on the sulfur K edge, in order to obtain information on the molecular orientation of the polymer chains in relation to the substrate, through angular variation of the incident light beam from 20¬∞ to 85¬∫. In the NEXAFS spectra obtained, two main transitions were observed, S 1s ‚Üí œÄ* e S 1s ‚Üí œÉ* (S-C), and through them it was possible to infer about the ordering and orientation of the polymer chains. At the same beamline, resonant Auger measurements were performed using the Core -Hole Clock (CHC) method, in order to investigate the charge transfer time of the analyzed polymeric films and thus con tribute to a greater understanding of the effects of additives and heat treatment in polymeric films. The investigated films were also characterized by X -ray photoelectron spectroscopy at IQ -UFRJ .
